At 28 Years Old, 'Learning How To Be A Sister'

StoryCorps: Recording The Lives And Stories Of Everyday Americans StoryCorps is an independent nonprofit project whose mission is to honor and celebrate the lives of everyday Americans by listening to their stories.

StoryCorps

Sharing And Preserving The Stories Of Our Lives
  • Visit StoryCorps.org

"I always wished for siblings," Alexandra Sanchez (left) tells Courtney McKinney during their April StoryCorps conversation in Dallas. Kevin Oliver/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Kevin Oliver/StoryCorps

At 28 Years Old, 'Learning How To Be A Sister'

June 15, 2018 After a DNA test revealed that they were half sisters, two women recall meeting each other for the first time. The discovery, for both of them, fulfilled a missing link.

At 28 Years Old, 'Learning How To Be A Sister'

2:28
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/619957265/620230432" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

At a StoryCorps interview in New York City, Allan Fuks (right) tells his former middle school classmate Spencer Katzman what it was like to go through school with an awkward name. Mia Warren/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Mia Warren/StoryCorps

He Grew Up With An Unfortunate Name He Hated Now He's Owning It

June 8, 2018 Allan Fuks' name subjected him to a childhood of teasing. Although the name-calling led his parents to legally change the family name, he recently decided to use it in his career as a comedian.

He Grew Up With An Unfortunate Name He Hated Now He's Owning It

2:39
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/617691679/618163055" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Juan Romero, 67, at his home in Modesto, Calif., holds a photo of himself and Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, taken by The Los Angeles Times' Boris Yaro on June 5, 1968. Jud Esty-Kendall/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Jud Esty-Kendall/StoryCorps

The Busboy Who Cradled A Dying RFK Recalls Those Final Moments

June 1, 2018 It's an infamous scene: Juan Romero, then a teenager, attends to Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, who had just been shot at LA's Ambassador Hotel. He reflects on his brief time with RFK 50 years ago.

The Busboy Who Cradled A Dying RFK Recalls Those Final Moments

3:39
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/615534723/616032009" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Cathy Sprigg (right) with her son, Army Spc. Robert Joseph Allen, at Tampa International Airport in 2010. Allen was headed back to Iraq after being on leave for the birth of his son. Courtesy of Cathy Sprigg hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of Cathy Sprigg

'He Had A Very Sad Heart': This Memorial Day, Remembering The Overlooked Heroes

May 26, 2018 A mother's once "happy-go-lucky" son took his own life in after serving in Iraq. Because of this, she feels he's not seen as a "hero," like his fellow soldiers which makes her loss more painful.

'He Had A Very Sad Heart': This Memorial Day, Remembering The Overlooked Heroes

3:56
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/613668913/614640449" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

In a StoryCorps conversation in 2016, Etaine Raphael (left) and Adele Levine reflected on their time as civilian physical therapists working with soldiers who had been severely injured while serving in Iraq and Afghanistan. John White/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
John White/StoryCorps

'If I Only Had A Magic Wand': Reflecting On Years Spent Working With Wounded Soldiers

May 25, 2018 Two physical therapists spent nearly a decade treating U.S. troops wounded in action. Despite their strong commitment to their patients, the job was emotionally draining.

'If I Only Had A Magic Wand': Reflecting On Years Spent Working With Wounded Soldiers

2:57
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/614061568/614315994" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Ginnie and Matt Peters on vacation in February 2011, a few months before he died by suicide. Courtesy of Ginnie Peters hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of Ginnie Peters

'He Was My Everything': A Farmer's Wife Reflects On Her Husband's Suicide

May 18, 2018 In May 2011, Ginnie Peters' husband, Matt, took his own life. In a StoryCorps conversation, she and Trent Andrews, a family friend, talk about Matt's last day and a letter he left.

'He Was My Everything': A Farmer's Wife Reflects On Her Husband's Suicide

3:11
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/611687746/612240927" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Max Knauer and his mother, Kittie Weston-Knauer, at a StoryCorps conversation recorded in April. Grace Pauley/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Grace Pauley/StoryCorps

'Why Don't You Try It?': How The Oldest U.S. Female BMX Racer Broke Into The Sport

May 11, 2018 Kittie Weston-Knauer and her son Max Knauer have spun bonding time into an extreme sport. Thirty years ago, Max egged her on to try BMX racing; at 69, she's still pedaling in races all over the U.S.

'Why Don't You Try It?': How The Oldest U.S. Female BMX Racer Broke Into The Sport

2:26
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/609738535/610315801" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

In a StoryCorps conversation recorded in February, Patrick and Tracia Kraemer recall falling in love at a nudist park. Kelly Moffitt/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Kelly Moffitt/StoryCorps

This Love Story Started At A Nudist Park

May 4, 2018 To celebrate her 40th birthday, Tracia Kraemer wanted to visit a nudist camp. She figured she'd wind up with a good story, but as she recalls with her husband, Patrick, she came away with a lot more.

This Love Story Started At A Nudist Park

2:35
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/607764107/608411434" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

In a 2009 StoryCorps interview, Charisse Spencer (right) shares with her son Myles Spencer-Watson her memories of growing up in Virginia during the 1960s civil rights movement. Lilly Sullivan/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Lilly Sullivan/StoryCorps

'We Were Representing Our Whole Race': A Mom Passes On Her Civil Rights Story

April 27, 2018 Charisse Spencer grew up in the country's largest black suburb during the 1960s. She tells her son about being one of the first African-Americans to integrate an all-white school in Virginia.

'We Were Representing Our Whole Race': A Mom Passes On Her Civil Rights Story

2:28
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/606028157/606292828" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Ralph Gagliardo was incarcerated for much of his daughter Abby's childhood. At StoryCorps, they talk about their relationship while he was in prison and after he returned home. Daniel Sitts/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Daniel Sitts/StoryCorps

'We Came A Long Way': After Prison, A New Chance For A Dad And His Daughter

April 20, 2018 For much of her childhood, Abby Gagliardo's dad, Ralph, was in and out of prison. But Abby, now 17, never understood why and she was hostile toward him when he finally returned home five years ago.

'We Came A Long Way': After Prison, A New Chance For A Dad And His Daughter

2:28
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/603903666/604241564" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Dennis Simmonds, 57, and his wife Roxanne, 54, during a visit to StoryCorps. Kevin Oliver for StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Kevin Oliver for StoryCorps

'He Wasn't Really Afraid Of Anything': Boston Bombing Victim Remembered

April 13, 2018 Five years after two explosions went off at the Boston Marathon, parents remember their son, Officer D.J. Simmonds, whose injuries suffered during a confrontation with the bombers led to his death.

'He Wasn't Really Afraid Of Anything': Boston Bombing Victim Remembered

3:03
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/601822573/602091076" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Davis, center, during his deployment to Afghanistan, where he served for nearly a year and a half as a human intelligence collector. Courtesy of Roman Coley Davis hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of Roman Coley Davis

A Young Soldier Finds Comfort In An Unexpected Delivery

April 7, 2018 Roman Coley Davis was stationed in Afghanistan when the loneliness of war began to seep in. He tells a friend how a surprise package from his hometown 7,000 miles away brought him immense solace.

A Young Soldier Finds Comfort In An Unexpected Delivery

3:25
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/600140283/600482884" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Brothers Russell Wadsworth, 28, (left) and Remmick Wadsworth, 27, both have autism. "To have a brother who shares something that you have, the same kind of emotions ... it just means the world," Russell tells his younger brother during a StoryCorps interview. Kevin Oliver/Courtesy of StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Kevin Oliver/Courtesy of StoryCorps

'You Would Always Have My Back': Brothers With Autism Navigate Life Together

April 6, 2018 As kids and now as adults, two brothers lift each other up and in turn, themselves as they face everyday challenges of living with autism.

'You Would Always Have My Back': Brothers With Autism Navigate Life Together

2:57
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/599738145/600055807" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

A 1950 photo of Kay (aka "Tubby") Johnston in her King's Dairy Little League team uniform hangs in a special exhibit honoring women in baseball, at the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. Courtesy of Kay Johnston Massar hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of Kay Johnston Massar

A Little League Of Her Own: The First Girl In Little League Baseball

March 30, 2018 At 13, Kay Johnston pretended to be a boy and played first base for a Little League team in upstate New York. That was in the 1950s. Now 81, Kay Johnston Massar says, "I just wanted to play the game."

A Little League Of Her Own: The First Girl In Little League Baseball

3:03
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/597960442/598192185" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

At their StoryCorps interview in Houston, Tanai Benard, 34, and her son, Dezmond Floyd, 10, discuss what's become a grim yet routine topic at schools: active shooter drills. Alletta Cooper/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Alletta Cooper/StoryCorps

'There Is No Handbook For This': A Mother And Son Talk About School Shootings

March 22, 2018 Recent school shootings are prompting many difficult conversations for families. In a StoryCorps interview, a fifth-grader and his mom discuss active shooter drills.

'There Is No Handbook For This': A Mother And Son Talk About School Shootings

2:36

More from StoryCorps

Encore: A Son On The Lessons He Learned From His Cabdriver Dad

March 20, 2018 In this StoryCorps conversation, a New York lawyer revisits pivotal moments with his Pakistani father. Their starkly different roads have brought them to similar conclusions about life.

Encore: A Son On The Lessons He Learned From His Cabdriver Dad

2:55
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/595426669/595430078" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">

'Hey, Taxi Boy': A Son On The Lessons He Learned From His Cabdriver Dad

March 16, 2018 In this StoryCorps conversation, a New York lawyer revisits pivotal moments with his Pakistani father. Their starkly different roads have brought them to similar conclusions about life.

'Hey, Taxi Boy': A Son On The Lessons He Learned From His Cabdriver Dad

2:40
  • Download

Lora Koenig with her son in the field at Russell Glacier in Greenland in 2011. Courtesy of Marilyn Koenig hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of Marilyn Koenig

'Mommy, You Can Do That': Navigating Work-Life Balance Thousands Of Miles From Home

March 9, 2018 Zoe Courville and Lora Koenig, colleagues and fellow climate scientists, spend weeks at a time away from their families doing research. At StoryCorps, they talk about their struggles as working moms.

'Mommy, You Can Do That': Navigating Work-Life Balance Thousands Of Miles From Home

2:51
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/591938105/592211590" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

In November 1965, Joe Galloway snapped this photo of his childhood friend Vince Cantu during the Battle of the Ia Drang Valley, without realizing who was pictured. Vince was rushing to pick up the body of American soldier in Plei Me, South Vietnam, to transport him home. The photo would ultimately run in several magazines. Bettmann Archive/Getty Images hide caption

toggle caption
Bettmann Archive/Getty Images

Childhood Friends Reunited In The Middle Of The Vietnam War

March 3, 2018 Vince Cantu and Joe Galloway first met in third grade. They lost track of each other in 1959, but met in an extraordinary scene in Vietnam and there's a famous picture to prove it.

Childhood Friends Reunited In The Middle Of The Vietnam War

2:54
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/588253823/590546449" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Actress Ashley Judd and her friend, Ted Klontz, outside Nashville, Tenn. Jill Glaser/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Jill Glaser/StoryCorps

Actress Ashley Judd's #MeToo Moment Was Driven By A 'Commitment' To Her Younger Self

March 2, 2018 In a StoryCorps conversation, Ashley Judd talks about being one of the first women to publicly accuse Harvey Weinstein of sexual harassment and about the "barn doors" that were flung open as a result.

Actress Ashley Judd's #MeToo Moment Was Driven By A 'Commitment' To Her Younger Self

3:24
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/589619992/590121865" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Joanna Wright, 58, and Tara Cummings, 47, spoke about their time at New Bethany Home for Girls during a StoryCorps conversation. Both women have testified that they were abused at the Louisiana school. Morgan Feigal-Stickles/StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Morgan Feigal-Stickles/StoryCorps

Finding Strength In Shared Stories Of Childhood Sexual Abuse

February 23, 2018 In a StoryCorps conversation, two women who attended the New Bethany Home for Girls in Louisiana talk about the abuse they say they experienced there and how it affected them years later.

Finding Strength In Shared Stories Of Childhood Sexual Abuse

2:51
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/586096174/588198821" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Cousins Cherie Johnson and James Ransom recorded their StoryCorps conversation in Sarasota, Fla. Courtesy of StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Courtesy of StoryCorps

'Good Morning, Miss Devine': Cousins Remember Their Sunday School Teacher

February 16, 2018 Cousins James Ransom and Cherie Johnson swap stories about the Sunday school teacher who taught and took care of two generations of the family.

'Good Morning, Miss Devine': Cousins Remember Their Sunday School Teacher

3:03
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/586180280/586315618" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

John Banvard, 100, and Jerry Nadeau, 72, tied the knot five years ago, in a wedding at their veterans home in Chula Vista, Calif. Cam Buker for StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Cam Buker for StoryCorps

2 Vets Celebrate Love: 'If You Came To See The Bride, You're Out Of Luck'

February 9, 2018 When Jerry Nadeau, 72, a Vietnam vet, met his husband, John Banvard, 100, a World War II vet, neither had been openly gay. Together now for almost 25 years, each says he feels completed by the other.

2 Vets Celebrate Love: 'If You Came To See The Bride, You're Out Of Luck'

2:38
  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/583998949/584451917" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Lan Cao, 53, with her daughter, Harlan, 12, at their StoryCorps interview in Westminster, Calif. in January 2015. During the interview, Lan tells her daughter about her experience during the Tet Offensive in Vietnam in 1968. Gautam Srikishan /StoryCorps hide caption

toggle caption
Gautam Srikishan /StoryCorps

A Former Refugee Reflects On The Vietnam War And Starting Over In The U.S.

February 2, 2018 Lan Cao was sent to the U.S. as a teenager from Vietnam in 1975. At StoryCorps, she tells her daughter about watching the Tet Offensive play out in her city and about adjusting to life in America.

A Former Refugee Reflects On The Vietnam War And Starting Over In The U.S.

  • Download

The body of Air Force Sgt. Leonard Matlovich is buried at Congressional Cemetery on July 2, 1988. Matlovich, recipient of the Bronze Star and Purple Heart in Vietnam, became a gay rights figure during his five-year battle against the Air Force, which discharged him in 1975 for homosexuality. In 1980 Matlovich settled with the Air Force and received an honorable discharge. Ira Schwartz /AP hide caption

Opinion

Relentless, Despite Losses: Congressman's Climb To The Hill

Opinion

Finding Health After Letting Go Of Hate

September 28, 2012 After he was told his brother had been murdered, Charlie Morris was filled with hatred. When he sought medical help for mysterious medical symptoms 10 years later, he realized it was his rage that plagued his body. When he started to forgive, he says his nightmares stopped, and his ailments went away.

National Teachers Initiative

Neurosurgeon Gives Thanks To His Science Teacher

September 25, 2011 As a middle-school student in the '80s, Lee Buono stayed after school one day to remove the brain and spinal cord from a frog. He did such a good job that his science teacher told him he might become a neurosurgeon someday. That's exactly what Buono did.

Reflecting On Sept. 11, 2001

Saving The Stories Of Loved Ones Lost On Sept. 11

September 8, 2011 The StoryCorps oral history project marks the anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001, with the voices of those directly affected by the attacks. Together with the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, StoryCorps is collecting stories about each person who died on that day. So far, more than 1,200 interviews have been recorded.

A Father Reflects On Strength And Meeting His Match

September 2, 2011 Robert Stover, 83, grew up moving from town to town. Born puny but bright, he tells his daughter, Valerie Anderson, 56, that he got beaten up a lot. Later, he married Valerie's mom, Kay, who was beautiful but scrawny and strong-willed. "She was my match. Some days, she was more than my match."

A Thanksgiving Feast For The Ears And Eyes

One Man's Yearly Thanksgiving Dinner For Strangers

November 19, 2010 Each Thanksgiving Scott Macaulay cooks dinner for anyone who wants to join him. In the past 25 years the tradition has grown from 12 people to more than 80. But Macaulay says he always hopes no one will make a reservation -- because that will mean everyone has someplace to go for the holiday.

Remembering a Tricky Name Change

June 6, 2008 Ramon Sanchez remembers growing up as a Mexican-American student in California in the 1950s, when teachers changed his name to Raymond. He wasn't alone. Girls named Maria became Mary. Juanita became Jane. Then Facundo enrolled and teachers didn't know what to do.

Remembering 'The Greatest Mom in the World'

May 9, 2008 Wanda Zoeller, the youngest of six children, was so poor growing up that her family had to keep borrowing a light bulb from one room to light another. Zoeller says her mother, who was the most important person in her life, made sure they didn't feel poor.

Leaving the Farm, Then Breaking New Ground

May 2, 2008 Lyle Link left his father's farm after deciding that picking corn and shoveling manure wasn't for him. He met his future wife, Marion, at church and never looked back. Now 90, Link describes the life they lived together and his heartache now that she's gone.

April 18, 2008 Joe Buford, 63, has a high school diploma but kept a secret, even from his family: He couldn't read. He managed to fool others into thinking that he could. And he was terrified that his inability would be passed on to his kids.

April 4, 2008 Forty years ago Friday, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot and killed in Memphis, Tenn. Sanitation workers, who were on strike in the city at the time, remember the indignities they suffered and the civil rights leader who came to support them.

  • Transcript

Finding a New Kind of Love, Late in Life

May 4, 2007 Ten years ago, two men met who would change each other's lives. Don Boniface was single, with AIDS. Ted Kuhar had only recently told friends and family he was gay. "I didn't know what this kind of love was," Kuhar said.

Finding a New Kind of Love, Late in Life

  • Download
  • <iframe src="https://www.npr.org/player/embed/9981593/9982671" width="100%" height="290" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" title="NPR embedded audio player">
  • Transcript

Parents Recall Daughter Who Changed Their World

April 27, 2007 Liddy Horsey was born with Cornelia de Lange Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder. She didn't reach her ninth birthday but she changed her parents' lives. Thom Horsey and Karen Manning Horsey recently spoke of how grateful they are.

Parents Recall Daughter Who Changed Their World
